Pay is substantial once you hit top pay

Long hours
Brown uniforms (dark colors absorb heat)
Brown trucks
150 pounds per package maximum. This is never followed either, I've seen and delivered multiple packages over 150 pounds. Total weight is not calculated either. I've had a customer live on the 3rd floor and demand delivery of over 350 pounds of goods and UPS told me to do it.

Job beats up your body if you're not careful.

cons: The team I was on was not bad, but there's way too many meetings for developers in my opinion. If you're not on a new project you'll be working on very old tech stake. They tend to overwork their developers instead of hiring resources to reduce the workload. Everything is priority so you'll be working like 2 to 4 projects either supporting and actively developing while attending all these meetings.

pros: Pros: Each interviewer can ask different questions that get at different aspects of a candidate and their experience. And with everyone in the interview, interviewers can compare and contrast candidates more easily afterward, which helps reduce personal bias. If there are multiple decision-makers for a role, a panel interview also makes it easy to include more people and complete the interview on time. Candidates also get a chance to meet more members of a company and see how they interact with each other in panel interviews.
cons: While group interviews are a great way for candidates and team members to learn more about each other, they may not be essential to qualify the candidate for the role. And often in group settings one person may dominate the interview and make it difficult to control the group dynamic.

review_title: Only work there if you're facing extreme poverty
pros: There are some minor pros but totally outweighed by the cons
cons: Management and HR don't care about the employees whatsoever. Poorly managed. Toxic work environment with no recognition of hard work and effort. Lacking integrity. Poor health and safety practices. Military structure- management will not communicate directly with you. Constant mind games and gaslighting. Advertising what an amazing company they are and how they value their employees but it's actually the height of hypocrisy. Service level is so bad, I'm surprised they actually have customers. Stay away if you want to remain sane. If, however you need to work for them, I recommend contacting a solicitor and going through every coma in the contract, be prepared to be thrown under the bus otherwise.

pros: UPS HR gets one working right away! UPS HR department processes people quickly. I enjoyed the onboarding process and training.
cons: Seasonal Work means one is on call Monday - Friday. One can extend out to Saturday, but know that UPS places their in-house (HUB) people to be Truck Helpers first, meaning they have seniority over new hires, so one is only called to work if the package volume is high, typically to work on average 4-5 hours. I need daily Mon - Friday consistent work and only learned this during my second week on the job. HR did apologize for not clarifying this with me at the time I applied for the position.

pros: The pay is one of the highest in the industry. The vacations are fairly flexible.
cons: UPS has a longstanding and enduring culture of aggression towards its people. I regularly in many locations see package handlers receiving the most vulgar language. It's common in many departments to be on unnecessary conference calls that don't contribute to learning, or an improvement in actual improvements in the attainment of business goals. Although (not from a lack of trying to improve this issue) the mostly male workforce contributes to an imbalance of power between genders in the work environment. Nepotism abounds, as its *although uncommon* its still an occurrence for family members to work in the same department and promote one another. Oversight in the HR department as it relates to arguments and sometimes actual fighting.

pros:
UPS does ALOT of things well. It has such a strong foundation and financial security. Our business capabilities are solid and plentiful. There is also much opportunity to get involved beyond day to day work with our Business Resource Groups. 
Also, our philanthropic arm of the organization is solid and our money goes far to help underserved communities
cons:
Compensation , that would be my biggest con. Pay is not competitive. For a Fortune 50 company with billion dollars in revenue, compensation is not competitive across the board. 
A lot of the entry level roles, are indeed NOT entry level and require general HR knowledge, however not communicated that way. 
Company doesn't do enough to keep millennial workforce engaged and interested.
Hierarchal culture kills the confidence of employees.

pros: Lots of benefits, if you last long enough to enjoy them
cons:
Misleading in hiring practices, but you don't know that until you begin working. The job of loading/Unloading but specifically the job of sorting is physically demanding. Don't believe anything they tell you. It is physically taxing on your upper body. Training and the job itself is not difficult. You have to memorize coding for sorting of packages and will take a bit to memorize but through the repetition you can memorize fairly quickly. What really makes the task of sorting is the mismanagement of the unloaders, who are not monitored properly, other than to move packages faster off the trailer regardless and consideration of the person on the other end trying to sort packages to the correct sorting belt. When you have packages that could way up to 70 lbs, and not just 1 package many times, it opens you up to unsafely moving packages in front of you, to behind you. When you get tired the injuries will come for lack of proper pace and concern for safety. Due to these and other bad training practices, I am surprised that I didn't hear of many injuries while my short stint there, but would not be surprised if the truth came out that there are more than I know or knew about. You will hear them talk a real good game about concern for safety and there practices, but there is a real lack of actually practice of safety.
My employment was to short know if the union was any good. I believe in Unions, but in my only interaction with them and paying union dues in my short stint, it was not worth it. Maybe because I was employed as part-time and such a short time, but you figure if you pay into the dues, the process to help would be a lot better to help in solving and making sure that hiring processes are honest and with integrity, regardless of employment status or length. So they get a thumbs down from me.

review_title: Not like any place I've ever worked!
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Englewood, CO
pros: Excellent health insurance (lots of coverage and easy to meet deductible) that covers all the family, including adult children until they're 26. If you last for at least 5 years, you'll get a small pension when you retire, even if you're young and have 40 years or more before you retire. You just got to know how to apply for it at retirement. There's also 401K plans. Early morning hours, out by 9 am usually, so you can have another job. They recently bumped the pay up to compete with Amazon, who just built a new facility across the street. You get OT after 5 hours daily and the sixth day is always OT. The drivers really appreciate when you ask them about how better to load their trucks according to their routes. It's great when they have a lot of package handlers to help when we get slammed, so we're not overwhelmed. You get 2 weeks of paid leave after a year and three weeks after 2 years. The schedule is flexible enough that management will give extra time off with enough notice. If you plan to stay more than a year, make sure you read the union contract and ask the union steward any questions or call your local union for information. Don't hesitate to do this because that's what they're getting paid to do. Just be professional about it.
cons: The harder you work, the more work you get. Management is always pressured to get more done in less time and with less labor. It's a union job, so right now most of us get the same pay (union contract dictates the pay) and there are some who do as little as possible. That means if you are killing it, then you will also be doing the work others should be able to do. Supervisors are not part of the union and should not be doing union work. They're not even suppose to touch packages, except in training new hires or when short staffed. They're supposed to make every effort to be staffed with union members. One time, union reps came to our facility, and the supervisors wouldn't dare even touch a box in fear that the union reps would see them. They are not part of the "bargaining unit". Everything is dictated in the contract that the union negotiates with the company. If you say anything to them about this, they will target you because you can get compensated for the work they did and took from you. I believe it's 3x the amount that you would have been paid. You do this by timing them when they do union work. It becomes stressful when you do grieve. They'll eventually leave you alone the more you grieve them because it stresses them also. Don't tell them and don't just make a threat to grieve, just do it. It's just easier that way.

review_title: You Will Be Doing Almost Everything
pros: You get guaranteed 27.5 hours a week at 20/hour, full benefits, and 401k and do get paid overtime. Great job if you wanting to get into management or work your way up the corporate UPS ladder.
cons:
If you are not fully staffed you will be working all of the jobs that aren't filled. This is contrary to your training (if you get trained) where they tell you that supervisors are not supposed to touch boxes. 

There's a lot of competition between you and other supervisors in other areas of the HUB you work at. Also, very confrontational. If you're doing something wrong you'll know. In team meetings they go over the previous days results and most full-time supervisors openly shame you and call you out for not meeting expectations or worse the full timers own expectations. 

Also, the people who work for you will probably not like you at first for whatever reason. If they do then that's great. But, when I became a supervisor I almost got into two fist fights with loaders in the first week. You have to follow protocol confidently because some loaders will actively try to get you fired, and you defeat them by just knowing the UPS protocols as well, if not better, than they do. It took me about a year for the loaders to finally respect me. You earn their respect by holding them accountable, being kind, and by being a leader.

You are not their friend you are their boss. Don't be a dictator, but be a leader.

You might have to break up fist fights between loaders who don't like each other. 

People quit constantly. It's rare that you have to fire anyone. It makes you believe that people are inherently not dependable, liars, and selfish. This job will prove that true, but it makes you appreciate the ones who are consistent and dependable that much more even if they don't like you. 

You will be working with people who don't have much education, and if you "talk smart" than they feel like you're talking down to them even though your not. This goes for management as well. I know full-time supervisors who never went to college and barely graduated high school. I'm not saying this makes them bad people or unqualified, but this is still a blue collar job. You're not working with people who all have engineering degrees your working with a lot different types of backgrounds. And at my particular HUB there's only one person who in my area who went to college, and they're a current college student.

If you don't speak Spanish it can be hard, but google translate is a beautiful thing.

You will have to write everything out like a lawyer, but everyone uses super vulgar language regardless of who's present. I didn't curse that much before this job, but now I could be a character in a Scorsese film and I have to actively stop myself from cursing and I find it weird when people don't curse.

You will live by the moto "Hope for the best. Prepare for the worst."

I took the job because of the tuition reimbursement program (I'm a college student), but the crazy hours were causing me to miss some classes and sleep through the rest. By the time this problem became apparent, I was committed. And the only way that I could pay for any of my classes, was to hang in there until the tuition reimbursement payout. They ended up paying me over a month later than promised, and I quit immediately afterwords.

review_title: Seasonal Personal Vehicle Driver for delivery not very organized
job_title: Seasonal Personal Vehicle Driver in Portland, OR
pros: Mostly really nice drivers and delivery truck drivers. (Some longtime truck drivers are really cranky), Lots of walking exercise, deliver on own, nice pay at $30 hour ($45 if over 8hours in a day or over 40 week). Weekly pay deposit. Daily start time usually 10am to 12noon. Sundays and Holidays off. Personal, and driving safety emphasized. My manager was always available for questions and that was encouraged. Dedicated cell phone with delivery software was often temperamental and not really meant to handle high holiday volume of seasonal drivers and pkgs. UPS hub seems to be very disorganized and has evidently made cuts that affect organization and in turn, the cost of providing excellent delivery/service. I am disappointed with how unorganized this company seems to be at the hub. Also frustrated with HR. There were 3 different contacts contacting me…and two months later I am still receiving instructions to meet my new hiring manager in two other suburbs! Also an inordinate number of repeated safety texts and msgs to watch videos and participate in safety questionnaires during your shift and after Work hours. Too many distractions during shift, but you have to look at them in case it is an important msg.
cons: Wait on-call daily (sometimes until noon) to find out if you are working that day. Sometimes not notified at all. Must be available Monday thru Saturday. Mgmt and regular truck drivers very stressed. Sounds like there’s a lot of yelling and screaming at hub in mornings. Trucks are overloaded at hub in very disorganized manner with no room to sort pkgs in stop order. (Loaders don’t seem to care, but maybe they are pressured to just get trucks loaded?) PVDs often end up helping drivers to sort outside trucks in rain and poor weather. Lots of waiting. Must be very flexible to work with various truck drivers who think they have the best way to do things…but every one of them make errors on PVD manifests. It is in the PVD’s best personal interest to ensure that their own vehicle has pkgs loaded in stop order so they can find anything as needed and to not waste delivery time looking for missing pkgs or having to revisit an address later with a “found” pkg while under pressure to deliver quota number of pkgs and higher…so others don’t have to deliver your quota late at night to finish. Do not expect more than part-time hours, with occasional opportunities for overtime. (Weekly pay deposits have been $500-1300). Expect wear and tear on your starter…or a lot of gas usage if you leave your car idling while delivering. (My suv used about a quarter tank daily, with reimbursed mileage for 7 to 23 miles daily).

job_title: Seasonal Driver Helper in Lenexa, KS
pros:
Working outside
Flexible schedule
My driver was great
Good hourly pay
cons:
'Orientation' was phrased via email as orientation, first day of work and as if it would be a phone call from a recruiter but that I was supposed to arrive ready for work....? The only location info included was a City, State & Zip. It turned out that I cleared that day and was prepared to work\go through an orientation but it was only a 5 minute walk-in to have someone copy your documents. I asked quite a few questions to the staff that was present that day since it was becoming clear that was the only way I would receive any solid info about how this job would work. They answered to the best of their ability; however, I was told you could work as many hours as you want but in reality there were not that many hours available per week. And the way the day-to-day communication between myself, dispatch and the drivers was explained that day was not in reality how it goes.
Dispatch does not always communicate in a timely fashion or well with the drivers regarding if you will be riding with them that day.
Amount/range of hours available to pick up were not communicated well and majority of the hours were in the middle of the day.
Contract was through Jan 15th but received a message on Xmas Eve saying that would be the last day of work and to turn in our vests. About a week later another message said they needed more helpers for the first couple weeks of Jan.
Details about the job were not provided, I had to ask alot of questions via text to dispatch to understand how the gig would actually work.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Easton, PA
pros: There's always some work everyday... but really this isn't reliable and it's not a good source of income
cons:
I worked in the small sort part of the warehouse. 

- The conditions are bad. It's very hot with pretty high humidity constantly. Requests for fans had been made to help with the heat but they were declined by management who sits in an air conditioned section of the warehouse.
- There are no breaks provided and no chances to take a breath during your shift. The work is constant, a lot of cardio. This is fine if you enjoy tasks with a seemingly never reachable goal.
- The bags that are used tear up your hands, purchasing gloves is a must if you don't want to leave with raw and bloody hands. Management does not reimburse for these gloves. 
- The managers on the floor in charge of you sometimes help, but usually only point out that you need to pick up your pace, even though there is clearly a deficit of workers for the volume of work demanded.
- The managers directly in charge of you could slow the volume of packages being sorted, to create a managable pace for the workers, but they don't do this. This is a sign of incompetence. 
- UPS lures you in with claims that they will help pay for college tuition, but in the sign up process they don't inform you that you need to remain employed by UPS just to have the CHANCE of receiving reimbursement for college tuition. It's very close to scamming.

I could keep going but basically, your life priorities are 1. UPS 2. UPS 3. Whatever else is important to you

pros: My overall experience working for UPS was really good. There were Great benefits and the location I worked at also had really good managers who were very nice and helpful. I also had the pleasure of working with some very friendly people. The work was not easy, but the atmosphere definitely helped to make it more enjoyable.
cons: My biggest issue was that we always seemed to be understaffed, but according to my manager it was because they weren’t allowed to hire anymore people. Which I believe to be true, because he wasn’t to happy about it either. My other complaint would be that we constantly had issues with the belts they seemed to have problems quite often. One of the biggest issues was that the belt would get weighed down very easily and we would have to stop unloading and help push the belt or take things off to get it moving again, even if there wasn’t that much on it. This would of course slow down our progress and was quite frustrating for everyone.
